reviewText: I still have moments where I see Alicia's husband as "Big" from Sex and the City...there even tend to be characteristics about his new role that are similar. The show has a great plot line and keeps you guessing what will happen next. An excellent use of each of the characters to keep you from growing bored with the same 4 stars repeating the same drama with only minor changes. I hope it continues to be a great program!

The writers on this show never disappoint!  There is always a twist or two leading to another twist or two. . . . They have set up Season 5 for us--we will have to wait to see what happens. When I think I have it figured out, something unexpected happens.  The new twist with the NSA is a good commentary about what's going on with our phone and email conversations; you just never know who's listening and what will be interpreted!  Did Diane really rat out Will?  Is Alicia rethinking her decision (again!) to go with the others to the new firm?

If you haven't been a rabid fan for the last 4 seasons, stream them or buy the complete seasons and get caught up!  We've been fans since the first season when a friend told us about the series!  We haven't missed a single episode since!  (Thank goodness for DVR!)  These writers are first class!

I have never enjoyed any of the courtroom or police dramas but this show is interesting and actually exciting. Very intelligently written with characters of some depth. The writers do the continuous background story very well and with each episode a self-contained story with a beginning and usually climactic ending.

This season's first two episodes looks like the show is actually getting better.

In general what I like about the show is its' exploration of liberalism. I mean REAL liberalism and not the Orwellian double-speak of today in which authoritarianism, intolerance, and love of the State is referred to as being "liberal". Whether it is feminism, guns, or religion it is presented through the lens of American liberalism. Instead of "sides" winning out it seems it is the Individual that is considered the most relevant entity - a complex Human that doesn't just swallow tribal rhetoric then spits out singular agendas. Much self-interest prevents such a thing and the show is unapologetic about this.

It is also fascinating to observe extreme objectivity, I mean "cut-throat" at times, and of course the Law is a perfect place to explore this.

It's sort of like the show "House" except it is a team of lawyers instead of doctors.

Please, review the product, not the delivery.  There is a chance that your computer is at fault and what we all look for is how is the drama, how do you like the show, the performances, the storyline, not whether your computer worked with it! I love this show. I have binge watched the entire series prob 4x over the course of a couple years. The newest season just ended last year, and a lot of times as a show gets age, it begins winding down, but not The Good Wife. It ends just as powerful as it began, and once you watch the series finale, go back and watch the pilot episode again. The first 10 min sequence  of the pilot and the final 10 min of the series, are essentially the same, although the characters have changed. We see the journey that Alicia makes, as the wife of a scandalous politician, from the background to the spotlight and how she learns to use the truth to her advantage. The series is totally believable as so many politicians have been caught up in sexual scandals, had to admit their wrongdoing to the public as their wives stand beside them to protect that "family" image so as not to commit career suicide, and if you look at the backgrounds of so many of those wives, they themselves are lawyers. Just look at Bill and Hillary Clinton and John and Elizabeth Edwards. It's sad that in American culture, the "image" of the scandalous husband and the educated wife standing by his side, this has become cliche'. Having said all of that, season 5 is not my favorite, but they had to do something to kinda change things up a bit. Alicia decides to join Cary Agos and the other 4th years and open their own firm, Diane and Will are out for blood in revenge, Peter becomes Governor of Illinois, Will is killed by his own client, Alicia starts a friendship with the new A.S.A, Finn Polmar, who tried to save Will's life, and against Diane's wishes, Louis Canning becomes the newest name partner at Lockhart, Gardner, and Canning.  The firm, Florence, Agos and Associates has to open in an old t-shirt factory and is far from the prestigious look of Lockhart Gardner. Some of our favorite guest stars return, but season 5 just doesn't have the cases or momentum of the previous 4 seasons. It fits along with the story lines, and isn't terrible, but isn't as great either. It's definitely worth watching and is necessary to continue to season 6. All in all, The Good Wife is one of my most favorite TV shows.

Also read the letter "Life Goes On" from Robert and Michelle King to the fans, which helped to ease the pain of losing Will. Thank you for that. Then I read another interview where it was Josh Charles decision to leave the show and how Julianna Margulies talked him into another 15 shows (16 since this is where he meets his demise), thank you Julianna!!. Still was so hard to see him go, I wish him the best in his future endeavors. I see where he is married and have welcomed a little one into their family. Funny since one of the reasons Julianna gave for him to stay with the show was the high cost of schooling for children. Now it won't be long before that will become a reality for him. I just completed Season 6 (binge watching again) and have enjoyed watching, although I did miss Will, it was nice they kept referring to him in some of the episodes. TV execs seem to have forgotten why people watch TV. It is not to experience real life, it is not for shock value, or to educate (although there are some informational programs on PBS and Discovery etc).  The reason we watch TV shows is to feel better afterward!  Most of us have enough ups and downs in our real life and enough routine blech that we really don't need to see a bunch of failures or sadness.  We like to see likable characters succeed most of the time - it feels good at the end of the show if they triumphed over the bad guys (who ever those are). Or if they are happy with a relationship that is going well. Obviously there needs to be some downs, some difficulties but we don't want to feel unhappy or down or disappointed at the end of most episodes. We like to triumph or succeed with them!  As others have noted by the 5th year or so, they seem to look for things to do and often choose to irreparably change the product in the process. It is so strange with such a successful, award winning ensemble they choice to make such a decisive and disappointing change.  Like Ziva leaving NCIS, the Good Wife will never be the same without Will Gardner!

Let me say here, that I'm not a fan of killing off characters in a TV series. For me, it shows a lack of imagination. But seriously, having a client shoot Will in the court room by grabbing the gun of a careless guard was a real stretch, and it's been done before on TV. And now the series has to keep exploring Alicia's grief - not just in season 5 but beyond. Enough already. This truly is pure soap opera material, and when The Good Wife began, it was much better than a night time soap drama. Unfortunately, the soap opera aspect is taking over more and more of the show. I'll still watch for the few episodes that are actually good, but I can see why the show is coming to an end. And, for me, the beginning of the end started with the writers taking Kalinda's character in the wrong direction in season 4. It's all over but the shouting.

Even though I came to this series late and binge watched them all on DVD in less than a week, I knew going in to this season that it was going to be a sad one because I had remembered back when the episode with the courtroom shooting aired that people had talked about it and articles had been written online about it but I was unprepared for the magnitude of feelings this season and this series inspires. First of all, kudos to Alicia for going with Cary. I'm not saying I liked the decision when I first watched because I really like Diane and Will and their relationships with Alicia and if it had been me being Alicia, I would have taken their offer and been with Will on the side. I like to think that even though it wasn't implicitly said that she went with Cary so that one day Will and her could be together, without threats of sexual harassment or people saying she used her relationship with Will to get ahead in the company. Although if she would've taken managing partner deal at LG, she kind of would have been his equal, well minus seniority and the fact that he started the firm so maybe they could've had the relationship in the open there too. Anyways, wills last episode was heartbreaking and I felt like they wrote the grief real. As one who has grieved people that have unexpectedly died, you do feel like that. I liked how Alicia was able to lean on Diane and Kalinda and even her family and Finn in her time of need. I'm really glad she didn't finish walking in the door to the bar when the business man juror was waiting for her because it was just too soon and would've cheapened her feelings for Will. I really wanted to smack Peter upside the head though when everyone was being nice to her and she missed something politically due to her grief being so strong she couldn't get out of bed and Peter being like well at least it wasn't your husband that had died. I get that but come on Peter, where was that love and respect for your wife when you cheated on her in the first place? I loved the scene where they were discussing their affairs and he was like mine didn't matter and she was like too bad because mine did. That was the closest she really came to admitting to anyone the depth of her feelings for Will. I was really sad that she couldn't even admit to Diane that she loved him. I really liked the flashbacks with Will and Kalinda about why Alicia's firm was going to fire her for not having a backbone because I think it showed that will would probably forgive her eventually if he had lived because somewhere between her husbands scandals, will being her boss, and all the other ups and downs, this season proved that Alicia does have a backbone and that she's not being pushed around by anyone anymore whether she loves them or not. I think the other female characters such as Diane and Kalinda gained a bit more of that this season as well. I really enjoy the fact that this show has such strong woman characters, both as career woman, girlfriends and wives, mothers, and a combination of them all. Although if it was up to me, I would've had will Gardner on their for every single episode of this series and a happily ever after ending, I really can't see this season playing out any other way now that I've watched all of it, but I'm still hoping will and Alicia will be back together sometimes in flashbacks and dream sequences.

For me, Will and Alicia's relationship was the driving force behind this show- the big story that held all the little stories in place and made them feel meaningful. Technically, the show can continue after Will's death, but it won't be the same show. This show was never about Alicia's personal growth- she has been supernaturally capable and intelligent from the beginning- it was about the battle between love and duty, passion and ambition, emotion and dry efficiency, played out between Will and Alicia.

After the show's great investment in this relationship, Will's sudden and meaningless death leaves a bitter and nihilistic taste in my mouth. What if Mr. Roger's Neighborhood featured Mr. Rogers choking to death on a cracker and the show continuing without him? What if Carrie and Miranda from Sex and the City had gotten blown up in the middle of a season?.

The only bright side is that Will's death has ended my addiction to this show. It did feel a bit ironic at times to spend hours curled up on the couch watching super-efficient characters run around accomplishing things.
